qas.question: The duplication and transmission of genetic material from one generation of cells to the next is the basis for what?
Why do organisms inherit the characteristics of their parents?

answers.text: cells of the offspring contain copies of the genes in their parents' cells

qas.question: In what type of organism will the offspring be a genetic copy or clone of the parent organism?
In what type of organism will a specialized form of cell division called meiosis produce cells called gametes?
What are the gametes produced by females called?

context: The duplication and transmission of genetic material from one generation of cells to the next is the basis for <a0_0>molecular inheritance<a0_0/>, and the link between the classical and molecular pictures of genes. Organisms inherit the characteristics of their parents because the <a1_0>cells of the offspring contain copies of the genes in their parents' cells<a1_0/>. <a2_0>In asexually reproducing organisms<a2_0/>, the offspring will be a genetic copy or clone of the parent organism. <a3_0>In sexually reproducing organisms<a3_0/>, a specialized form of cell division called meiosis produces cells called gametes or germ cells that are haploid, or contain only one copy of each gene.:20.2 The gametes produced by females are called <a4_0>eggs or ova<a4_0/>, and those produced by males are called sperm. Two gametes fuse to form a diploid fertilized egg, a single cell that has two sets of genes, with one copy of each gene from the mother and one from the father.:20
